Award.AwardTitle: Processing an Additional Quantity of Ge-76 for the Majorana Demonstrator
Award.AbstractNarration:
A comprehensive program in neutrino-less double-beta decay is very timely. A principal finding of the APS Multidivisional Study stated: "We recommend, as a high priority, a phased program of sensitive searches for neutrino-less nuclear double-beta decay." The intellectual merit of this award is based on the fact that the observation of such a decay is the only practical way to determine if neutrinos are Majorana particles (their own antiparticles). This exotic decay is the most sensitive test of lepton number conservation, an important symmetry in elementary-particle physics. In fact, if neutrinos are Majorana particles, a measurement of the decay half-life would yield the effective Majorana mass of the electron neutrino. This result, combined with neutrino oscillation data, would determine all three neutrino-mass eigenvalues. Is leptogenesis even a possibility? Yes, but only if neutrinos are Majorana particles.

These funds are awarded to assist the Majorana Demonstrator (MJD) experiment searching for neutrino-less double beta decay in germanium -76 (Ge-76). The specific and limited work is to carry-out the highly technical conversion of germanium oxide (GeO2) into metallic form suitable for the fabrication of Ge detector units. The PI leads the Task in the MJD R&D Project responsible for the procurement of enriched GeO2, its reduction to metal, zone refinement to detector quality Ge metal, and reprocessing of the scrap material. The PIs formed the team that equipped the facility and acquired the necessary equipment for the Ge processing and reprocessing; they are now operating the facility. Recently two Russian Institutes have agreed to loan MJD between 8.7 and 14.5-kg of enriched GeO2. The cost of processing this material was not covered in the original proposal. Accordingly, this funding is provided for the reduction, zone refinement and reprocessing of this material, and for new R&D to develop more efficient scrap reprocessing. This new loaned GeO2 will significantly extend the science reach of the MJD.

Broader impacts:
One broader impact would be an important contribution to cosmology. Another is, and has been, new detector technology for National and Homeland security. A third broader impact is new ultra-low background Ge-detector technology for other basic and applied sciences. In fact, this technology has broad application in environmental radiological surveys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this grant was in direct support of the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR Experiment. This is an experiment to search for a rare radioactive decay in which a nucleus decays by the emmission of two electrons, but without the emmission of neutrinos. This exotic process is called neutrinoless double-beta decay, and is forbidden unless neutrinos (which are emmitted in all other forms of beta decay) have mass and are their own anti-particles (called Majorana particles). Neutrinos are the most prolific elementary particles in the universe, but interact so weakly with matter that much about them is still a mystery.

A leading puzzle in cosmology is the fact that in the Big Bang creation, particles and antiparticles were produced in pairs, and in the very early universe as it  expanded and cooled, particles and their anti-particles underwent annihilation also in pairs. The puzzle is, why is the universe we observe today even here? And, why is it constituted entirely of particles with no measurable content of anti-particles?

One possible candidate theoretical explanation is called "leptogenesis." This process would require that there would have been a very tiny asymmetry of particles over anti-particles in the early universe that evolved into today's particle-dominated universe. For the process of leptogenesis to occur, Majorana neutrinos are involved in the theory, hence they would have to exist.

It turns out that the observation of neutrinoless double-beta decay is the only practical way to prove that neutrinos are Majorana particles. In addition, the measurement of the rate of this decay mode could be used with other neutrino data to determine their mass scale. Accordingly, the sensitive search for neutrinoless double-beta decay would potentially have very important impacts on the fields of elementary particle physics, nuclear physics, astrophysics and cosmology.

The MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR (MJD) is an array of ultra-low background, point-contact, germanium (Ge) detectors. The detectors are made of germanium enriched in the isotope germanium-76, the candidate isotope for this exotic decay. Therefore, the detector is also the decay source. Ge detectors are in common use in laboratories; however, the natural abundance of Ge-76 is less than 8%. To construct a very sensitive experiment, the Ge used in MJD was enriched by a gas centrifuge technique in a specialized facility in Russia. The cost of this enriched Ge was about $100/gram. To make high quality Ge detectors, the Ge metal used must be ultra pure. The use of standard Ge industry techniques to purify the Ge, would be far too expensive because of the required efforts to minimize losses. In addition, no industrial company was interested in processing the MJD germanium because of the responsibility for possible losses in case of an accident.

To address this problem, the MJD Collaboration decided to set up its own Ge processing facility. Accordingly, the PI and Co-PI wrote a proposal to hire experts to transfer the general technology to MJD, to purchase the needed equipment, rent space, and set up a facility to reduce the imported Ge in oxide form to metal in hydrogen reduction furnaces, to zone refine the metal to detector grade, and to chemically reprocess the scrap material in various forms. After several years of operation funded by this and a previous grant, 42.5-kilograms of Ge, enriched to 86% in Ge-76, were purified and turned into 35 working detectors with a total mass of  29.68 kilograms. The present grant supported the processing of the last 5-kilograms of Ge.Twenty of these detectors are operating in the first modular MJD array in the Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF) in Lead South Dakota. The data acquisition phase of the MJD experiment started in the winter of 2015, and the Ge processing Task was completed and decommissioned in April 2015.
